I hope we can learn from this. We have enough problems without inventing bogeymen—either from those who repeatedly peddled the collusion narrative or from those who baselessly attacked Mueller’s integrity. We need to work together to ensure this does not become business as usual.

Key individuals who should have known better lied to the public, and in doing so, did serious harm to our national security. They disgraced themselves and, unfortunately, damaged the reputations of their institutions and the many honorable men and women in the IC.

As a former intelligence officer, I’m gravely concerned by the way the intelligence community (IC) became politicized over the past two years. Officials like Comey, Clapper, Brennan, and Schiff eroded public trust in our IC by wading too deeply into politics and innuendo.

The simple fact is our media did itself no favors over the past two years. All too often, it delved into clickbait conspiracy rather than objective journalism. This can’t continue, because we really do need the media to hold politicians accountable.

Just imagine for a minute being so opposed to the President that you actively wished he was disloyal to the country and was an agent of a hostile foreign power. It’s crazy and demonstrates the extent to which shallow political combat has become our new national religion.

Which leads to another ugly truth. All Americans should be glad there was no collusion. But you wouldn’t know it by all the disappointed faces on cable news, some of whom are now questioning the integrity of Mueller and Barr.

Part of getting to work means coming to terms with the ugly truths underlying this saga and ensuring something like this never happens again. That means we not only need full disclosure of the report, but also the process that gave rise to the investigation in the first place.

Obviously we need the full report, but AG Barr made his conclusions clear. We need to stop with collusion conspiracy theories and the efforts to change the 2016 election, and get to work on the real problems facing this country.

Since day one, I’ve emphasized the need for a full and impartial investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Many of my Democratic colleagues called on Republicans to put aside party and stand on principle with Mueller. We did that. Now they must do the same.
I've spent the past few days observing the reactions to the findings of Special Counsel Mueller's investigation. I wanted to share my candid thoughts on Mueller's report below. ⬇️

We can also take steps to strike back at the swamp. This week, I introduced a bill that would prevent former Members of Congress, retired flag and general officers, and former senior executive branch appointees from lobbying on behalf of foreign interests. https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/gallagher-introduces-new-drain-swamp-legislation …

Luckily, we can fight back. Earlier this year, @reprubengallego and I introduced bipartisan legislation to hold Chinese telecom firms, like @Huawei, accountable for their malign behavior and cut off their supply of critical US technology.

Huawei's lawsuit is a good example of how the CCP uses the swamp to try to change US policy. It is engaged in an all-out offensive targeted at lawyers, lobbyists, and journalists to save itself and influence our society.

Since @Huawei is "the most open, transparent and scrutinized company in the world," I'm sure it would love to provide a full accounting of the role of its internal Communist Party Committee, as well as a complete roster of CCP members it employs. https://www.huawei.com/en/press-events/special-release/john-suffolks-statement-at-huawei-press-conference-on-march7-2019 …
